what: Predict Method for Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — predict.streg
title: Predict Method for Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — predict.streg
text: Obtain model-based predictions parametric proportional hazards survival model fitted streg().

title: Predict Method for Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — predict.streg
code: # S3 method for streg predict(object, newdata = NULL, type = "xb", se.fit = FALSE, ...)

title: Predict Method for Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — predict.streg
text: object fitted streg() object. newdata Optionally, data frame look variables predict. NULL (default), predictions computed data used fit model. scenario, passing streg() model fitted argument x = TRUE required. type type prediction required. default "xb" return linear predictor. possible predictions hazard function (type = "hazard") survival function (type = "survival"). se.fit Logical switch indicating standard errors required. ... used.

title: Predict Method for Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — predict.streg
text: se.fit = FALSE, vector required predictions. se.fit = TRUE data.frame returned column predictions (named fit) column fitted standard errors (named se.fit).

title: Predict Method for Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — predict.streg
text: newdata omitted predictions based data used fit.

title: Predict Method for Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — predict.streg
text: Standard errors estimated using numerical delta method, implemented rstpm2::predictnl() --- equivalent, principle --- Stata's predictnl command.

title: Predict Method for Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — predict.streg
code: library(streg) data("kva", package = "streg")  # Fit a model fit <- streg(Surv(failtime, event) ~ load + bearings, data = kva, distribution = "exp", x = TRUE)  # Predict the hazard for each subject predict(fit, type = "surv") #>  [1] 0.4534698 0.4110771 0.3530038 0.3493923 0.2940474 0.3103658 0.3436591 #>  [8] 0.4378607 0.3416486 0.3055314 0.4485186 0.4156529  # Predict the survival probability, including a standard error for the fitted value predict(fit, type = "surv", se.fit = TRUE) #>          fit    se.fit #> 1  0.4534698 0.2160007 #> 2  0.4110771 0.2201323 #> 3  0.3530038 0.1790433 #> 4  0.3493923 0.1789790 #> 5  0.2940474 0.1503516 #> 6  0.3103658 0.1516996 #> 7  0.3436591 0.1533435 #> 8  0.4378607 0.1510580 #> 9  0.3416486 0.1787424 #> 10 0.3055314 0.1764592 #> 11 0.4485186 0.2166310 #> 12 0.4156529 0.2197878  # Predictions for a new dataset nd <- data.frame(failtime = 30, event = 1, load = 10, bearings = 3) predict(fit, newdata = nd, type = "surv") #> [1] 0.913497 predict(fit, newdata = nd, type = "surv", se.fit = TRUE) #>        fit    se.fit #> 1 0.913497 0.1320159

what: Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — streg-package
title: Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — streg-package
text: Survival analysis parametric proportional hazards survival models, including exponential, Weibull, Gompertz model. Model-based predictions supported well, e.g. predicting hazard survival function.

title: Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — streg-package
text: Alessandro Gasparini (alessandro.gasparini@ki.se)

what: Fitting Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — streg
title: Fitting Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — streg
text: streg() used fit parametric proportional hazards survival models.

title: Fitting Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — streg
code: streg(   formula,   data,   distribution = "exponential",   x = FALSE,   y = FALSE,   init = NULL,   control = list() )

title: Fitting Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — streg
text: formula formula describing model fitted. left-hand-side formula must survival::Surv() object, (moment) right censoring supported. data data frame containing variables model (described model formula). distribution character string naming distribution assumed baseline hazard function. Possible values "exponential", "weibull", "gompertz" exponential, Weibull, Gompertz parametric survival regression models, respectively. See 'Details' informations . x Logical value indicating whether model matrix used fitting process returned components fitted object. y Logical value indicating whether response vector (survival::Surv() object) used fitting process returned components fitted object. init optional vector starting values fitting process. NULL (default), starting values obtained (1) fitting empty model parameters related distribution (2) assuming coefficients start value zero. control list parameters controlling fitting process, passed stats::nlminb().

title: Fitting Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — streg
text: object class streg.

title: Fitting Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — streg
text: general parametric proportional hazards survival model defined $$  h(t | X, \theta, \beta) = h_0(t | \theta) \exp(X \beta) $$ \(X\) represents model covariates, \(\theta\) represents ancillary parameter, \(\beta\) represents regression coefficients; \(h_0(\cdot)\) baseline hazard function. exponential model assumes following baseline hazard function: $$  h_0(t | \theta) = \lambda $$ practice, \(\lambda\) incorporated linear predictor modelled log-scale (reported (Intercept) model). Weibull model assumes following baseline hazard function: $$  h_0(t | \theta) = p \lambda t^{p - 1} $$ \(\lambda\) incorporated linear predictor modelled log-scale (reported (Intercept) model); \(p\) also modelled log-scale reported ln_p. Finally, Gompertz model assumes following baseline hazard function: $$  h_0(t | \theta) = \lambda \exp(\gamma t) $$ \(\lambda\) incorporated linear predictor modelled log-scale (reported (Intercept) model), \(\gamma\) reported gamma constrained strictly positive, Stata.

title: Fitting Parametric Proportional Hazards Survival Models — streg
code: library(streg) data("kva") fit <- streg(Surv(failtime, event) ~ load + bearings, data = kva, distribution = "exp", x = TRUE) fit #> Exponential regression -- log-relative hazard form #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)         load     bearings   #>    -5.75660      0.06112     -0.21948   #>
